experience for someone to become a

well he was totally puzzled he had no

it's like going into a battle without

plan you can decide what you want to do
because
i found
that the practice of law
in this country is really quite simple
there are three precepts that you have
to follow
first you have to answer everything
now when you come into court and
represent yourself
the lawyers and the judge
consider you as fresh meat they're going
to tie you apart
so the first thing the opposing lawyer
will do
is file a set of written interrogatories
against you
and he will ask you the most personal
questions and the most
questions which will make you very
indignant and you say i am not going to
answer this this is illegal it's
unconstitutional
so i refuse to answer
then you go back into court
and the opposing lawyer immediately asks
for a default judgment against you
because you have failed to answer the
interrogatories
and the judge immediately grants that
judgment and you lost your case right
there
so that's why i say answer everything
and the second precept is
always deny everything
you can admit your name but do not admit
anything else because anything else you
admit or agree with
they're going to use against you
now this of course is contrary
to the american way i mean we are
decent
and sensible people
and if someone makes a charge of some
kind that there is a little truth we'll
say well yes uh i admit that there is a

those other circumstances mean
absolutely nothing the fact that you
have admitted even one percent of what
they're charging you with you
immediately fall into their clutches and
it's all over
so that's why i say answer everything
deny everything and the third precept is
answer on time
in the courts they operate on very
strict time sequences usually you have
21 days to answer something a motion or
a complaint and so forth
and you have to be extremely careful
to
stay within those time limits
now this is not true of lawyers
